snippet: As reports of assaults by Syrian forces continued for a fifth day, Russia’s leaders attempted to fend off criticism that they were doing nothing effective to stop the bloodshed.
abstract: Russia’s leaders try to fend off international criticism that they are doing nothing effective to stop the bloodshed in Syria, arguing that Moscow’s efforts are far more productive and balanced than the combined Western and Arab plan; Sergey V Lavrov, the foreign minister, stresses that Russia will seek to inaugurate open negotiations between the government and the opposition.

byline.original: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
byline.contributor: Neil MacFarquhar reported from Beirut, and Michael Schwirtz from Moscow. Hwaida Saad and an employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Beirut, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: As reports of assaults by Syrian forces continued for a fifth day, Russia’s leaders attempted to fend off criticism that they were doing nothing effective to stop the bloodshed.

headline.seo: In Syria, Russia Defends Diplomacy Amid Reports of Violence
headline.main: Russia Defends Its Diplomacy in Syria Amid Accounts of Escalating Violence
headline.print_headline: Russia Defends Its Diplomacy in Syria Amid Accounts of Escalating Violence

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
